Legal_Provision_Violated: paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Facts: Applicant delayed filing due to depression; medical evidence provided but investigator concluded disability did not prevent timely filing
Procedural_Issue: Request for time extension under paragraph 41(1)(e)
Decision_Outcome: Commission refused to extend time limit
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to file human rights complaint
Legal_Standard_Applied: Commission may extend time if deemed appropriate under paragraph 41(1)(e)
Decision_Rationale: Commission reviewed all materials and found no basis to extend time; decision not patently unreasonable

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Institutional_Action: Investigation by Canadian Human Rights Commission
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Person with disability seeking workplace accommodation
State_Protection_Assessment: Accommodation efforts limited by incomplete medical disclosure
Credibility: Partial credibility due to limited information sharing by complainant
Legal_Provision: Section 5 and Section 14 of the Canadian Human Rights Act
State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate procedural fairness found despite investigation gaps

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of employment due to medical restrictions
Legal_Framework: Federal Court Act, Canadian Human Rights Act
Decision_Outcome: Application granted, case remanded for reconsideration
Credibility: Complaint supported by investigation report and response
Perpetrator_Entity: Employer (implied), Canadian Human Rights Commission (procedural failure)

Legal_Issue: Jurisdictional and timeliness issues in complaint dismissal
Governing_Law: Section 41(1) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: EI benefits issue was improperly dismissed due to delay without prejudice shown; YMCA incident lacked jurisdiction
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision quashed for reconsideration on EI benefits claim only
Burden_of_Proof: On complainant to establish jurisdiction and timeliness
Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly assessed, but timeliness affected credibility of claim process
Legal_Rule: Section 41(1) allows Commission to dismiss complaints lacking jurisdiction or filed untimely
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged discrimination by HRDC regarding EI benefits and YMCA incident
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached for EI benefits; dismissed for YMCA incident due to lack of jurisdiction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of complaint filing, nature of HRDC involvement, connection to federal jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Commission argued complaint was out of time and outside jurisdiction
Outcome: Partial success: judicial review ordered on EI benefits issue only
Legal_Provision: Section 41(1) of the Canadian Human Rights Act

Dispute_Type: Employment discrimination, specifically related to dismissal and alleged delay in filing complaint
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing allegations 3 to 6 as out of time and whether the applicant's reasons for delay were sufficient
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's personal reasons for delay and pursuit of alternate recourse were considered but found insufficient by the Commission
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to justify the delay in filing beyond the one-year period
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanation for delay included personal circumstances and use of alternate dispute resolution channels
Legal_Rule: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act allows complaints beyond one year if the Commission considers it appropriate
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged discriminatory dismissal by the RCMP
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on procedural grounds due to untimeliness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of dismissal (December 19, 2001), date of complaint filing (October 24, 2003), applicant's explanations for delay
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, timeliness requirements under federal anti-discrimination legislation
Defendant_Response: RCMP's position not detailed, but Commission accepted procedural bar based on delay
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (dates of employment actions), personal explanations from applicant
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's decision to dismiss the complaint as untimely
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court on judicial review

Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in refusing to address a delayed complaint
Evidence_Assessment: Lack of documentation and impaired witness memory due to delay
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonable exercise of discretion
Credibility_Factor: Diminished credibility of evidence due to time lapse
Legal_Rule: Section 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act – discretionary refusal of late complaints
Grounds_for_Claim: Sexual discrimination in employment by rejecting female junior driver
Outcome_on_Merits: Commission's decision upheld; complaint not investigated
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of complaint filing (October 1998), occurrence date (June 1997), availability of records, witness recall
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but Commission justified refusal based on delay and prejudice
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to compel investigation of discrimination complaint
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Procedural fairness in human rights tribunal proceedings
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant can obtain an interlocutory injunction to halt tribunal proceedings pending judicial review
Governing_Law: Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application; motion for interlocutory injunction
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to utilize opportunities provided by the Commission to submit new evidence
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must prove: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Legal_Rule: Interim order under s. 18.2 requires: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience favoring applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness due to lack of opportunity to present new evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; injunction denied on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Opportunities provided by the Commission for evidence submission
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Tribunal process; Federal Court judicial review powers
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to pause tribunal proceedings
Outcome: Injunction denied; tribunal proceedings allowed to continue

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Complaint of discrimination based on disability
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 41(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Institutional_Action: Commission allowed late-filed complaint and proceeded with investigation
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under the Canadian Human Rights Act
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Respondent claimed disability due to alcoholism
State_Protection_Assessment: Commission exercised discretion to extend time limit
Risk_Factor: Perceived delay leading to procedural unfairness
Credibility: Court found no unreasonable prejudice from delay
Legal_Provision: Section 41(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
State_Protection_Adequacy: Procedural fairness maintained; Commission acted within jurisdiction
Risk_Nature: Procedural fairness and timeliness of complaint

Dispute_Type: Allegation of discriminatory remarks by immigration officers
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in law by dismissing a discrimination complaint due to lack of evidence and credibility issues
Governing_Law: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting evidence, lack of corroboration, prior investigations found no misconduct
Burden_of_Proof: On the complainant to establish credible evidence of discrimination
Credibility_Factor: Credibility issues with the complainant's allegations
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss a complaint if an inquiry is not warranted based on all circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: No sufficient evidence to proceed; complaint dismissed on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Complainant's testimony, lack of supporting witnesses, prior investigation findings
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but prior investigations concluded no misconduct
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's dismissal decision
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act

Crime_Name: Discrimination complaint under the Canadian Human Rights Act
Dispute_Type: Human rights discrimination complaint regarding timeliness and discretionary extension
Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission erred in finding the complaint time-barred and failed to exercise discretion for an extension
Evidence_Assessment: Timing of key decisions and communications, including CIC's final decision in June 2004 and a letter from July 2003
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision set aside; matter remitted for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to justify delay and request for extension
Legal_Rule: Complaints must be filed within one year unless an extension is granted by the Commission
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that limitation period began in June 2004; challenge to Commission's procedural fairness and reasoning
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: July 2003 letter as point of crystallization, December 2001 event cited by Respondent, June 2004 CIC decision
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, administrative law principles on discretion and procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Argued that limitation period began in December 2001
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of Commission's decision, remittal for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Complaint dismissed as out of time
Grounds_for_Claim: National origin, disability, retaliation for prior complaints
Institutional_Action: Commission declined to deal with complaint
Protected_Group: Persons with disabilities, ethnic/national origin minorities
Credibility: Claim not assessed on merits due to timeliness
Legal_Provision: Section requiring complaints within one year unless exceptional circumstances apply
Victim_Basis: National origin, disability, prior exercise of human rights

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Mr. Cardin spent significant time in Canada including schooling and work, but was absent for 688 days due to a U.S.-based training program.
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the three-year physical presence requirement under Pourghasemi test
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge applied Pourghasemi test strictly without considering alternative tests (Papadogiorgakis or Koo)
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, ties to Canada, employment, education history
Decision_Outcome: Denial of citizenship application by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by a different Citizenship Judge
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge's strict application of the Pourghasemi test was unreasonable given Mr. Cardin's deep ties to Canada and long-standing connection to the country.
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court on appeal

Credibility_Assessment: Credible applicant claims on family impact
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 36

Credibility_Assessment: Credible applicant claims on family impact
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 36

Credibility_Assessment: Credible applicant claims on family impact
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 36

Credibility_Assessment: Credible applicant claims on family impact
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 36

Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show irreparable harm and serious issue
Legal_Rule: Tri-partite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience

Residency_Compliance: Lawful resident at time of offense
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider children's best interests
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction to grant stay
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of consideration of humanitarian factors
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed, stay granted pending judicial review
Decision_Rationale: Children's best interests constitute a serious issue

Crimes.Crime_Name: Willful blindness to crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted knowledge of torture but did not participate; was a low-ranking officer who avoided involvement in abuses
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Deserted Sri Lankan Police Force in 1997
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: CRDD initially excluded based on willful blindness; Federal Court found decision unreasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of knowledge of torture, rank and role in police force
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence of personal participation or knowing complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear of persecution by both LTTE and government forces
Crimes.Outcome: Case referred to new panel for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal and knowing participation required for exclusion under Article 1F
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere presence or willful blindness insufficient for exclusion; no proof of active complicity

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status due to alleged complicity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity through membership in Sri Lankan Police Force
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, international criminal law
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Federal Court review of CRDD decision
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State protection inadequate; applicant feared persecution from both state and non-state actors
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Fear of persecution by LTTE and government forces
Crimes.Credibility: Found credible regarding desertion and fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Persecution based on political opinion and association
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Real risk of harm due to perceived disloyalty

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed residency in Canada but had discrepancies in declarations and evidence regarding absences
Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate at least 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada during the four years preceding application
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent and incomplete evidence regarding absences from Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Applicant's declarations, supporting documents on travel and residence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete and inconsistent evidence provided by applicant
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge found doubts about the completeness and credibility of applicant's claims
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that Applicant met residency requirements
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence of at least 1,095 days in Canada within four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable and based on thorough analysis of the evidence
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with authorized stay conditions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a Chinese citizen, cook by profession, applied for a work permit but was refused due to insufficient proof of ties to home country, low income, lack of assets, no international travel history, and presence of family in Canada.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No evidence of compliance with residency obligations; concerns about intent to leave Canada after authorization period
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview conducted; procedural fairness assessed based on whether extrinsic or subjective factors were used
Evidence_Used: Lack of significant assets in home country
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of strong personal, financial, and familial ties to China
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's intent to return to China not credible
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question for appeal or quashing of the refusal decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant must demonstrate intention to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant repeatedly failed to prove they would leave Canada after their authorized stay
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of temporary work permit application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer acted reasonably in refusing the work permit due to insufficient proof of ties to home country
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR), particularly sections related to temporary resident applications
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s establishment in China deemed insufficient; credibility of intent to return undermined by weak socio-economic ties
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPR Section 20(1)(a) – requirement to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant failed to meet burden of proving they would depart Canada after work authorization ended
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of strong financial and familial ties to China, combined with presence of relatives in Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision under administrative law principles
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant bears burden to prove they will leave Canada after temporary stay

Governing_Law: Principle of mootness in judicial review
Application_Facts: Visa officer revoked immigrant visas; new visas were later issued
Claimant_Status: Applicants whose visas were revoked and reissued
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No live controversy due to reissuance of visas
Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to challenge visa revocation
Standard_of_Review: De novo or correctness standard for legal questions
Decision_Rationale: Underlying controversy resolved by reissuance of visas; no adversarial context or useful purpose for declaratory relief

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in finding that the applicants were not persons in need of protection under subparagraph 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA?
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Generalized crime risk vs. personal risk
Assessment_Standard: Personal risk not generally faced by others
Legal_Standard: Person in need of protection under IRPA
Application_Factor: Generalized crime due to perceived wealth

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in finding that the applicants were not persons in need of protection under subparagraph 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA?
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to prove personal risk
Legal_Rule: Personal risk not generally faced by others

Perpetrator_Type: Unknown actors linked to organized crime/general criminality
Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of targeted persecution on Convention grounds

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee protection criteria
Application_Facts: Family targeted due to perceived wealth
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of personal targeting

Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of state involvement or Convention ground

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of torture due to wealth and activism
State_Protection_Adequacy: Generally lacking but not specific to applicants

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in finding that the applicants were not persons in need of protection under subparagraph 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA?
Document_Fraud: Falsification or misrepresentation in official documentation

Application_Facts: Wellesley Therapeutics sought to market disulfiram in Canada; drug had been previously withdrawn; company argued 50-year history established safety and efficacy; Health Canada required clinical trial data for new drug approval
Procedural_Issue: Health Canada failed to conduct a substantive review of the NDS application; relied on approvals of other drugs without proper analysis
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Health Canada cited insufficient evidence from Wellesley but did not adequately review submitted literature and data
Decision_Outcome: DIN application (T-706-10) dismissed; NDS application (T-1537-07) allowed; Health Canada's rejection deemed unreasonable
Outcome: Health Canada must reconsider Wellesley’s NDS application considering all submissions and literature provided
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Health Canada’s refusal to approve disulfiram for marketing
Remedy_Sought: Order requiring Health Canada to reconsider the NDS application
Decision_Rationale: Health Canada acted unreasonably by failing to properly assess the NDS application and relying on irrelevant comparisons to other approved drugs without adequate justification

Governing_Law: IRPA, sections related to refugee protection and review by RAD
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to fear of forced marriage; inconsistencies noted in testimony regarding uncle’s role and authenticity of marriage contract
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony raising concerns about truthfulness
Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to conduct independent review; applied insufficient analysis in upholding RPD's credibility determination
Evidence_Used: Testimony, documents related to family relationships and marriage contract
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of thorough examination of evidence on uncle’s involvement and marriage contract authenticity
Credibility_Assessment: RPD and RAD found credibility issues; RAD did not adequately reassess
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by RPD and upheld by RAD
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a protected person under IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal questions
Decision_Rationale: RAD did not provide sufficient reasoning in upholding credibility findings; review was inadequate
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence linking general conditions in Haiti to personal situation
Legal_Provision: s. 25, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence
Legal_Rule: s. 25 IRPA – humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Convictions for multiple crimes including drug trafficking and assault
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of personalized risk evidence regarding Haiti
Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship established

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of Narcotics for the Purpose of Trafficking
Risk_Nexus: No direct personal risk established despite health and family ties
Basis_for_Decision: Lack of unusual or disproportionate hardship

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal on H&C grounds
Evidence_Assessment: All factors considered but no undue hardship found
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show exceptional circumstances

Basis_for_Decision: No unusual or disproportionate hardship proven

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of denial of H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Factors considered but insufficient to establish hardship

Violation_Type: Failure to establish persecution or lack of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Mexico as a homosexual, citing police harassment and societal discrimination
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Incidents described by applicant, country condition information
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that incidents amounted to persecution or that state protection was unavailable
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on objective sufficiency of evidence
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of negative refugee determination
Decision_Rationale: Board found incidents isolated and not escalating; internal flight alternative and state protection available in Mexico

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status as an Ahmadi sympathizer but was deemed not credible by the Board.
Misrepresentation_Element: Lack of credibility in applicant's claim
Procedural_Issue: Board did not notify applicant of reasoning or allow response; absence of hearing transcript
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No hearing transcript available to assess credibility findings or procedural fairness
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible by the Board
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied based on credibility
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness, right to be heard, sufficiency of record for judicial review
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with attention to procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient record and lack of procedural fairness due to no notice or opportunity to respond on credibility concerns

Crimes.Crime_Name: Subject to a removal order under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was issued a removal order due to non-compliance with residency obligations; appeal ongoing but does not stay removal order.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal process does not stay enforcement of removal order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order documentation, citizenship application records
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of removal order, approval of citizenship application
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Individual remains under a removal order until appeals are exhausted and order is quashed; eligibility not restored during appeal.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet minimum physical presence requirements; departure order issued and under appeal.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident (pending final determination on removal)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ongoing appeal does not negate existence of removal order for citizenship purposes
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Residency tracking records, immigration status history, appeal filings
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ineligible for citizenship due to being under a removal order
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Recognition of permanent resident status, cancellation of removal order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) and (f) of Citizenship Act and IRPA s. 46(1)(c)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Despite retention of permanent resident status pending appeal, applicant is under a removal order and thus ineligible for citizenship.

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 691 days over four years; worked internationally; claimed Canada as primary residence under 'centralized mode of existence' test from Re Koo
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge made errors in factual findings (e.g., employment dates, passport stamps); failed to properly apply legal test by comparing residential connections between Canada and other countries
Evidence_Used: Passport stamps, employment records, residency history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inaccurate assessment of passport stamps and employment dates
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralized mode of existence test from Re Koo
Decision_Rationale: Original decision was unreasonable due to factual errors and misapplication of the legal test; failure to compare residential ties between Canada and foreign jurisdictions

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Bloxom spent only 421 days in Canada during the relevant four-year period
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – 421 days out of required 1095 days
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge considered irrelevant factors; judicial review sought on procedural grounds
Evidence_Used: Record of Bloxom's physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or proof of residency meeting statutory threshold
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; original decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Bloxom did not meet the mandatory 1095-day physical presence requirement; statutory compliance is objective

Application_Facts: Applicant, Li Zhang, claimed residence from October 2, 2002; accumulated only 922 days of physical presence in Canada within four years before application, falling short of the required 1095 days.
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenged the reasonableness of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Dates and records of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or proof to establish 1095 days of residence
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to insufficient residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge correctly applied the law; no reviewable error was found. The qualitative test was not applicable because the applicant did not meet the physical presence threshold.

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate lack of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by SSP in Pakistan due to religious affiliation; alleged insufficient state protection against sectarian violence
Residency_Compliance: Claimant was in Canada and seeking refugee status; residency status pending determination
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Pakistan's efforts to control sectarian violence, including military and police presence and government initiatives
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to prove state inability to protect nationals in Pakistan
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant failed to demonstrate lack of state protection; credibility not explicitly challenged but burden of proof not met
Standard_of_Review: Patently unreasonable standard applied to Board's findings
Decision_Rationale: State protection does not need to be perfect; Pakistan maintains functional military, police, and civil authority making serious efforts to protect citizens despite challenges with sectarian violence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose change in marital status constitutes misrepresentation under s. 27(1)(e)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of ignorance rejected
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Signed immigration documents declaring accuracy of information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to update marital status before entry
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to disclose material facts regardless of intent
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation includes non-disclosure of material facts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration through omission in official forms

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant married before landing but did not report it
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking entry as single individual
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with disclosure requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of notification of marital change
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ignorance not accepted as defense
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to disclose material fact constitutes misrepresentation regardless of intent

Violation_Type: Denial of refugee status based on credibility issues
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed political persecution in Haiti; principal applicant's testimony contained contradictions, such as obtaining a birth certificate during alleged detention
Claimant_Status: Principal applicant and spouse seeking refugee status
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent testimony by principal applicant affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: Board disregarded corroborative evidence due to credibility concerns
Evidence_Used: Testimony of principal applicant, supporting statement from spouse
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony undermined reliability of evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board found principal applicant not credible due to material inconsistencies
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision denying refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision fell within range of acceptable outcomes; credibility findings supported by record
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with removal order due to custody arrangement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant, a Nigerian citizen, has two Canadian-born children; Ontario Court granted her custody and prohibited child removal from Ontario; removal officer argued deportation does not contravene custody order as physical proximity is not required.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Nigerian citizen with custody of Canadian-born children
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No – subject to removal order after failed refugee and humanitarian claims
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether Ontario custody order triggers automatic stay under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Conflict between provincial family court order and federal immigration enforcement authority
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Ontario Court custody order, removal order, submissions by Minister
Crimes.Outcome: Removal stayed temporarily pending appeal resolution or expiration of appeal period
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Prevention of deportation based on custody rights
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 50(a) of IRPA – enforcement must directly contravene a judicial decision where the Minister had opportunity to make submissions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Custody order does not require physical presence; deportation does not 'directly contravene' the order; precedent does not support such interpretation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA Section 50(a) and general residency provisions
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada on temporary status, overstayed visa after unsuccessful refugee and humanitarian claims; obtained Ontario custody order for Canadian-born children; argued removal violates court order.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Nigerian citizen, former temporary resident, parent of Canadian citizens
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No – overstayed visa and subject to removal
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Interpretation of IRPA Section 50(a) in relation to family court orders
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Overlap between immigration enforcement and provincial family law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa history, refugee claim records, humanitarian application outcome, Ontario custody order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Cancellation of removal order based on best interests of children and custody rights
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal under IRPA Section 50(a), protection under Charter and international conventions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 50(a) of IRPA – requirement of direct contravention of judicial decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Deportation does not directly contravene custody order; physical proximity not mandated by order; prior jurisprudence rejects similar arguments

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were previously rejected; they submitted a PRRA alleging religious persecution in Ukraine
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants seeking PRRA protection
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to pending removal order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged risk not sufficiently substantiated with new evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer assessed new evidence and credibility without re-litigating prior decisions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, applicant submissions, documentation from interested parties
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of personalized risk of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably weighed credibility and relevance of evidence, including from interested parties
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reversal of PRRA decision and grant of protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for reconsideration or declaration of invalidity
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No substantial risk of persecution established based on new evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA – failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after refugee claims were denied and applied for PRRA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired visa and refusal of status renewal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: None found; focus was on risk assessment, not fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Evaluation of new evidence in PRRA context despite prior adverse findings
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's supervisory jurisdiction over PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: New documents, country condition updates, personal affidavits
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, specific, and current evidence demonstrating personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility concerns carried forward reasonably from prior decisions
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and remittal for re-assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No objective basis to conclude applicants face a danger of persecution upon return

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and authenticity of claimed persecution risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer reasonably evaluated new evidence and credibility
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer assessed but did not arbitrarily dismiss evidence from interested parties
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, letters from religious groups, media reports
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 97–98 IRPA (PRRA eligibility and risk assessment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged religious persecution as Pentecostals in Ukraine
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of individualized risk despite generalized societal prejudice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: PRRA assessment followed by Federal Court judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: None identified; officer properly exercised discretion
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence outright ignored; some deemed insufficiently relevant or dated
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing, source reliability, and specificity of evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No finding of forged documents; concerns related to probative value

Crimes.Crime_Name: Religious persecution claim denial under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Denial of protection based on religious persecution claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA Sections 96, 97(1), and international refugee law principles
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution due to Pentecostal faith in Ukraine
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No subjective or objective basis for fear of persecution established
Crimes.Institutional_Action: PRRA assessment concluding no substantial risk
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canada, under federal immigration and refugee protection regime
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Failed refugee claimant seeking protection via PRRA
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Christians, particularly non-Orthodox denominations in parts of Ukraine
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State able and willing to protect religious minorities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Generalized social discrimination, not state-sponsored or condoned violence
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but insufficient to establish personal risk
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate legal and practical protections available
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Societal prejudice without evidence of systemic persecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Non-state actors and societal elements, not government authorities

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Minister vacate a refugee status decision if it was obtained through misrepresentation or withholding material facts?
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for fresh determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Gunasingam misrepresented his travel timeline and used a false passport, affecting credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Passport documentation, travel records, country condition reports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation in obtaining refugee status through fraudulent documents
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false passport and inconsistency in travel narrative
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial Review of Refugee Protection Division Decision
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Original decision relied on conjecture rather than evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Material omissions regarding travel and use of false document
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Materiality of misrepresented facts to refugee claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; remanded for new hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: Withholding Material Facts in Refugee Claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a refugee claim be vacated if it was obtained through misrepresentation or withholding of material facts?
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Gunasingam omitted stay in Malaysia and misrepresented travel dates
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of material facts affecting eligibility for refugee protection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to disclose presence in Malaysia, a safe third country
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial Review of Refugee Protection Division Decision
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient reasoning and lack of procedural fairness
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Assessment based on completeness and truthfulness of information
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of prior stay in Malaysia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality of withheld facts under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Relevance and significance of omitted travel history
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision vacated and remanded due to inadequate reasons

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a refugee claim be vacated due to misrepresentation or withholding of material facts?
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for new determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Gunasingam misrepresented travel dates and omitted Malaysian stay
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Travel documentation, interview transcripts, country condition reports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False statements and omissions in support of refugee application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Reliance on conjecture instead of verified evidence by decision maker
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Minister’s application to vacate status, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Original decision failed to properly assess tainted vs. untainted evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether sufficient untainted evidence supported original grant
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in timeline and unexplained gaps in travel history
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Extent to which misrepresentation influenced the outcome
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for fresh determination due to flawed reasoning
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false passport and fabricated travel details

Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer improperly refuse the applicant's request for permanent residence by misclassifying his occupation and failing to conduct a fair assessment?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review via certiorari and mandamus
Evidence_Assessment: The visa officer failed to evaluate the applicant's work experience in the designated category (5133-126) despite evidence of relevant experience.
Decision_Outcome: The application succeeds; the visa officer's decision is set aside.
Legal_Rule: Under the Immigration Act and Regulations, visa officers must thoroughly assess applicants' qualifications and provide fair evaluations. Applicants have the right to frame their applications to maximize entry chances.
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Misclassification of the applicant's occupation and failure to assess alternate occupations inherent in his work experience.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court found in favor of the applicant.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's claimed experience as a 'Commercial Traveller', evidence of relevant experience in category 5133-126.
Remedy_Requested: Re-assessment of the applicant's case by a different visa officer
Outcome: The court ordered a re-assessment of the applicant's case by a different visa officer, ensuring compliance with immigration laws.
Authority: Visa officer, Court conducting judicial review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the IAD's decision to uphold the visa officer's refusal based on a genuine marriage reasonable?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, S.O.R./2004-167
Crimes.Outcome: IAD's decision set aside, case remanded for rehearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage questioned due to incompatibility and lack of credible interaction
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Marriage not genuine if entered into primarily for immigration benefits
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Visa officer deemed marriage not genuine
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: New evidence not addressed by IAD

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Permanent residency application appeal based on spousal sponsorship
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the marriage between Amar Singh and Geeta Rani genuine or entered into primarily for immigration purposes?
Crimes.Outcome: IAD's decision set aside, case remanded for rehearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage found not genuine due to minimal knowledge, incompatibility, and lack of communication
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Marriage not valid if not genuine and entered into primarily for immigration status
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Suspicion of marriage fraud based on relationship inconsistencies
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: IAD failed to address new evidence contradicting initial findings
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to evaluate newly submitted evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet work experience requirements for work permit
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had no prior cooking experience but possessed relevant certifications; LMO required three years of food service experience
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment based on documentary evidence without interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of verifiable work experience in cooking
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; qualifications accepted but insufficient
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and issue work permit
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded applicant could not perform required work due to lack of experience
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer reasonably refused the application due to lack of experience
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s qualifications credible but experience lacking
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient work experience despite other qualifications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Three years of required cooking experience not met
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet explicit job requirement stated in LMO
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of inability to perform work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Experience requirement was mandatory per employer’s LMO

Outcome: Court allowed judicial review, set aside decision, remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Assumption made about applicant's intent to return without opportunity to respond
Evidence_Type: Applicant's ties to Colombia, study history in Canada
Basis_of_Claim: Assumed lack of intent to leave Canada after studies
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of opportunity to address concerns about intent to return
Application_Error: Failure to provide applicant chance to clarify intent
Evidence_Ignored: Potential evidence of ties to Colombia
Legal_Standard: Natural justice, fairness in administrative decision-making
Application_Factor: Duration of study in Canada affecting perceived ties to home country
Decision_Outcome: Denial of study permit and temporary resident visa

Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for fear
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony, impact of PTSD on recall
Legal_Rule: Credibility assessments must be reasonable and justified
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of blood feud in Albania
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Outcome: Decision quashed, case referred to differently constituted RPD

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the applicants failed to give Colombian authorities a reasonable opportunity to investigate their claims of persecution
Governing_Law: Canadian refugee law, presumption of state protection in democratic nations
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient effort to pursue formal investigation with Ministry of Defence
Application_Error: Failure to provide Colombian authorities a reasonable opportunity to investigate
Legal_Standard: State protection unavailable despite presumption in democratic countries
Application_Factor: Prior engagement with police and military

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate reasonably concluded that the Applicant would not be at risk if returned to Pakistan
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, matter remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant claimed risk of torture due to inclusion on CBSA's wanted list
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on human rights conditions in Pakistan, reports of torture in detention
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of torture or cruel treatment upon return to Pakistan
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Selective interpretation of evidence by delegate
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately justify conclusions based on evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Widespread reports of torture in Pakistan, personal risk factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personal risk of torture or cruel and unusual treatment under Section 97

Crimes.Application_Facts: Pakistani citizen overstayed visa, claimed protection in Canada, refugee claim denied
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness and independence of decision-maker
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Minister's Delegate under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on country conditions in Pakistan
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to link generalized risk to personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s risk deemed generalized rather than personal
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal risk of torture under Section 97 of IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Selective interpretation of evidence, unsupported conclusions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate reasonably concluded that the Applicant would not face a risk if returned to Pakistan
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, remitted for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant linked to terrorism, faces significant risk upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on torture in Pakistani detention centers
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of torture due to alleged terrorism links
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Selective interpretation of evidence by delegate
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent findings and failure to consider relevant evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Widespread reports of torture in detention centers
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personal risk of torture or cruel treatment under Section 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Alleged terrorism affiliation increasing risk profile

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Section related to authorized stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Moumaev remained in Canada beyond the validity of his visa after fleeing Russia due to fear of persecution.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral of removal made post-overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Reissued birth certificate indicating Chechen ethnicity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to consider new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: New documentation supported ethnic identity, previously unverified
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on risk and new evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal pending PRRA application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: As soon as reasonably practicable enforcement under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider exceptional circumstances rendered decision patently unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Enforcement Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Section on enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Moumaev remained in Canada after a removal order was issued despite claiming risk upon return.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant subject to removal
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral based on new evidence not adequately assessed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Restored birth certificate confirming Chechen origin
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer ignored new documentary evidence of ethnicity and risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence deemed credible by Court despite prior doubts
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed; removal deferred pending second PRRA
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian and protection grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and stay of removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exceptional circumstances may justify deferral under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Focus on non-compliance without assessing risk constituted error

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C consideration despite immigration violations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Birth certificate and personal history submitted to support claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application not yet decided; deferral sought
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compelling circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Supporting documents strengthened credibility of ethnic and risk claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C considerations may override removal if exceptional circumstances exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of persecution, family ties in Canada, rehabilitation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application pending; deferral granted via judicial intervention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Reissued birth certificate, country condition reports
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.25(1) – Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Enforcement officer prioritized compliance over H&C factors
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal to allow H&C assessment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Risk of persecution based on ethnicity
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, UN Convention Against Torture
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on Chechen ethnicity in Russia
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights law, domestic refugee protection statutes
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Removal order challenged on risk grounds
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Federal Court
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Chechen national fearing state and non-state persecution
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Chechens in Russia facing systemic discrimination and violence
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Russia unable or unwilling to protect Chechen returnees
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of torture, arbitrary detention, and extrajudicial killings of Chechens
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate protection in country of origin
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Serious harm including torture and persecution

Crimes.Violation_Type: Procedural failure in risk assessment process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA - Sections governing PRRA and risk evaluation
Crimes.Application_Facts: Moumaev sought PRRA based on new evidence of Chechen ethnicity and risk
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national with prior negative refugee determination
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to overstaying and pending removal
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess new evidence in PRRA context
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Reissued birth certificate establishing Chechen identity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded material evidence relevant to risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: New evidence improved credibility of claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA refusal led to removal order enforcement attempt
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and re-assessment of risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ignoring new risk evidence without justification is unreasonable
